question: Why will Fir experience temporary unavailability of some compute nodes?
answer: Some compute nodes on Fir will be temporarily unavailable to support the commissioning of new cooling equipment.

question: When will Fir operate below full capacity?
answer: Fir will operate below full capacity from Monday, August 25 through Thursday, August 28, with normal capacity resuming by Friday, August 29.

question: What impact will the Fir reduction have on jobs?
answer: Fewer jobs will run at the same time, jobs may start more slowly, and wait times may be longer on Fir during the reduction period.

question: When was the Graham compute cluster retired?
answer: The Graham compute cluster was retired on September 1, 2025.

question: Do users need to take action for files stored on Graham after its retirement?
answer: No action is required for files stored on Graham as they are already available on Nibi because the two clusters share the same file systems.

question: Where should users submit jobs after Graham's retirement?
answer: Starting September 1, users should submit their jobs to another cluster on the new national infrastructure, including Nibi.

question: What was the duration and status of the Béluga, Narval, and Juno outage?
answer: The outage for Béluga, Narval, and Juno occurred from July 15, 2025 to August 11, 2025 (extended to September 8) for 55 days, and it has been completed.

question: What services were affected during the tape storage system migration for Béluga, Narval, and Juno?
answer: The tape storage system behind the TSM service, including file backup and restore services, and migrated /nearline data, was unavailable.

question: What happened to file backup and restore services during the tape system migration?
answer: File backup and restore services were unavailable. Restores of data created before July 15 resumed once the tape system returned to service, but data created or modified between July 15 and August 11 cannot be recovered.

question: Were files in /nearline accessible on Béluga and Narval if migrated to tape during the outage?
answer: No, files in /nearline that had been migrated to tape were not accessible on Béluga and Narval during the outage.

question: What TSM service functionality was impacted?
answer: The TSM service itself was fully unavailable during the migration.

question: Were other storage systems, compute nodes, and Juno Cloud instances operational during the tape system outage?
answer: Yes, other storage systems, compute nodes on all clusters, and Juno Cloud instances remained fully operational.

question: How will Globus transfers function during the tape system outage?
answer: Globus transfers will function normally except when accessing tape-migrated /nearline files.

question: How will the Resource Allocation Competition (RAC) be impacted by the infrastructure transition?
answer: The RAC will be impacted by the transition, but the application process remains the same.

question: When will the 2025/26 RAC allocations be implemented?
answer: The 2025/26 RAC allocations will be implemented everywhere once all new clusters are in service.

question: What happens if a user holds both a 2024 and 2025 RAC award during the transition?
answer: Users holding both a 2024 and 2025 RAC award will experience a period when neither award is available to them.

question: When can users compute with their default allocation on new clusters?
answer: Users will be able to compute with their default allocation (def-xxxxxx) on each new cluster as soon as it goes into service.

question: What is the course title for the self-guided training on SciNet and Trillium?
answer: The course title is 'HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium'.

question: Who provides the 'HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium' course?
answer: SciNet provides the 'HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium' course.

question: What is the estimated time to complete the 'HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium' course?
answer: The estimated time to complete the 'HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium' self-guided online course is approximately 4 hours.

question: Who is the 'Migrating to the upgraded national systems' webinar intended for?
answer: This webinar is for prospective users of the upgraded systems.

question: Who is the instructor for the 'Workflow Hacks for Large Datasets in HPC' webinar?
answer: Alex Razoumov is the instructor for the 'Workflow Hacks for Large Datasets in HPC' webinar.

question: When was the 'Workflow Hacks for Large Datasets in HPC' webinar held?
answer: The 'Workflow Hacks for Large Datasets in HPC' webinar was held on Tuesday, May 20, 2025, at 10:00 AM PT.

question: Where can users find recordings and materials for the 'Workflow Hacks for Large Datasets in HPC' webinar?
answer: Recordings and materials for the 'Workflow Hacks for Large Datasets in HPC' webinar are freely available at https://training.westdri.ca.

question: What is the purpose of the 'Mastering GPU Efficiency' course?
answer: This course provides basic training for Alliance users on using GPUs on national systems, measuring GPU utilization, and using NVIDIA MPS and MIG to improve efficiency.

question: What is the format of the 'Mastering GPU Efficiency' course?
answer: It is a 1-hour self-paced online course with a certificate of completion.

question: When is the 'Introduction to the Fir cluster' webinar scheduled?
answer: The 'Introduction to the Fir cluster' webinar is scheduled for September 2025 (rescheduled).

question: Who is the audience for the 'Survival guide for the upcoming GPU upgrades' presentation?
answer: The audience includes prospective users of the upgraded systems, especially those intending to use a substantial amount of H100 resources (e.g., more than one GPU at a time, and/or over 24 hours runtime).

question: What NVIDIA technologies are discussed in the 'Survival guide for the upcoming GPU upgrades' presentation?
answer: The presentation discusses NVIDIA's MPS (Multi-Process Service) and MIG (Multi-Instance GPU) technologies.
